Quantum theory is a branch of mathematics, and as such it is subject to the same mathematical foundations as other branches of mathematics. This paper provides a purely categorical mathematical foundation for quantum theory. The axioms are based on the mathematical structure of Hilbert spaces and the basic mathematical operations on them. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, but a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to the essential elements for survival as parasites. Our findings suggest that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zinc is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each proton channel subunit. Climate change will affect the global food supply, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use historical data on maize yields and climate variability to quantify how maize yields will change in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase dramatically. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize for heat tolerance.

The coexistence of species in a world of limited resources is a fundamental question in ecology. In this paper, we show that the coexistence of large mammalian herbivores in a semiarid African savanna is linked to the degree to which they partition food resources. We show that the degree to which species consume grasses is a reliable predictor of their diet composition, and that this is a strong determinant of dietary overlap. Our results suggest that the coexistence of large mammalian herbivores in savanna ecosystems may be more linked to plant diversity than previously thought.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses are planning to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris, which involve a combination of processes, including nano-fragmentation of the plastic, transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Our results point at the importance of the size distribution of floating plastic debris, which is a key factor in the fate of this pollution.

The age of the Solar System is one of the most important questions in astronomy. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have cosmogenic nuclides that were produced in the interstellar medium. We found that the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also found that a majority of the grains have ages of >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is fatal within a few years after disease onset, and no treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process. Here we report the results of a proof of concept study in a mouse model of MSA, which showed that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the progressive toxicity of alpha-synuclein aggregation in the striatum of the mouse model. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated alpha-synuclein and its oligomers, and with a preservation of tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA by limiting alpha-synuclein accumulation. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the use of VX-765 in MSA. This study also highlights the importance of the caspase-1 pathway in the pathogenesis of MSA. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the first cell layer to come into contact with blood. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling blood pressure, blood flow, and hemostasis. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell that is able to control these functions by processing information from multiple sources. This information is processed by a network of cells that are connected to each other in a way that allows for the rapid and efficient exchange of information. This study reveals the nature of the communication network that the endothelium uses to control its functions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, and the need for timely, accurate, and accessible data has never been greater. We present the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 surveillance signals, including traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This platform is intended to empower researchers and policy makers to track the pandemic and its impact, and to empower decision-making. We hope that the platform will be useful to many.

Potassium channels are a large family of ion channels that are involved in a wide variety of physiological and pathological processes. They are involved in the control of heart rate, blood pressure, and breathing, and in the propagation of nerve impulses. They are also involved in the pathophysiology of epilepsy, cardiac arrhythmia, and muscle weakness. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in potassium channels. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem of bacteria, archaea, fungi, and other microorganisms that play important roles in the health of the host. The role of fungi in the gut microbiome is less well understood, but they are known to be important in the digestive process. Here, we report the discovery of natural products from anaerobic fungi, which are a group of fungi that are poorly characterized and have not been extensively mined for the biosynthetic enzymes of natural products. We report the discovery of a diverse set of natural products from anaerobic fungi, including antibiotics, and provide evidence that these fungi synthesize these natural products. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are important in the production of natural products that could be used in the development of therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased reactive oxygen species production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. The design of mechanical devices with desired behaviors is a critical issue for the development of smart and intelligent systems. However, the design of a single device with a specific behavior is limited by the material properties and structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design mechanical devices with arbitrary behaviors by digitally synthesizing multiple materials into composite structures. The synthesized structures are seamlessly integrated into architectures with complex behaviors. The proposed strategy can be extended to design mechanical systems with specific behaviors, which can be further applied to the design of intelligent systems.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin pattern in human erythrocytes is a function of the developmental stage of the erythrocyte. The hemoglobin pattern is also a function of the age of the individual. This study demonstrates that the IGF2BP1 protein, which is expressed in erythroid cells, can affect the developmental stage of the hemoglobin pattern in human erythrocytes.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. We found that mutation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, highly frequent in cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance, and that this resistance is mediated by sustained activation of mTORC1 and the transcriptional activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central regulator of lipid metabolism. Conversely, ectopic expression of SREBP1 sensitized cancer cells to ferroptosis. In vivo, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction resulted in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is associated with the up-regulation of the Ca2+ sensor protein STIM1. Our findings suggest that the use of LCCBs should be carefully considered in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird species, but that the policy failed to reverse the decline of older forests. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and the need to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work is a proof of concept that computational design of antibiotics can be a powerful tool for the development of new drugs. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, and the number of parameters required to achieve accurate results is often large. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and that consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly, but the impact of this exposure on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the next-morning alertness and performance of healthy young adults. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth system. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope composition of the magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites is consistent with terrestrial sources, and that the rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the adult is unknown. Here, we report the results of a study in which we abrogated CTLA-4 expression in adult mice. We found that this resulted in a spectrum of autoimmunity, which was not fatal, but was accompanied by a profound expansion of Treg cells. This study provides a framework for understanding the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the history of beetle evolution remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls. Our results show that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the size of the population may be a critical factor in the evolution of the human species. This work has implications for the evolution of human culture and the origins of human intelligence.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the mantle by a sharp boundary. It is one of the most mysterious parts of the Earth, and its formation is still a matter of debate. One of the most important questions is how the inner core formed. We show that the bcc phase of iron is more likely to nucleate than the hcp phase, which is the most stable phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as increased craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors associated with marijuana abuse.

Language is the uniquely human ability that has most changed our world. Yet, despite its importance, the language-processing mechanisms in the human brain are only just beginning to be understood. Here, we show that artificial neural networks trained on large datasets of brain activity predict both the brain’s neural and behavioral responses to language better than any previous model. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also provide a framework for future model improvement, yielding a potential path forward in our quest to understand the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a general property of deep learning, but rather a consequence of the specific problem settings. We prove that there are problems where the deep learning algorithms are well-conditioned, and thus can be used to solve the problem. This is a significant step toward the practical use of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major global crisis. It is also a major opportunity to learn about the human condition. This article discusses the psychology experiment that is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. It shows that the experiment’s design flaws were not only overlooked at the time but also, in hindsight, undermine the conclusion.

The study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is a central problem in the field of quantum many-body dynamics. It is also of fundamental importance in statistical physics, as it is the origin of thermodynamics. However, the dynamics of entanglement and entropy is not trivial in general, and it is only recently that a complete understanding of the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit became possible. Here, we present a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy, which is the entanglement accumulated during the dynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing, and there is a need for a safe and effective vaccine. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine candidate is protective in hamsters, and the vaccine strain is highly attenuated. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This is the first report of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its history is important for understanding the history of human societies. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is the most recent period in which plague was widespread in Europe, and it is important to understand the history of this period to understand the history of plague in Europe. We developed a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector, and we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the dynamic actin cytoskeleton. It is thought to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is unclear. Here, we show that the action of ADF is strongly influenced by the mechanical properties of the actin network. We show that the mechanical torque exerted by the network on the filaments is critical for understanding the ADF-induced severing of the network. Our results have implications for understanding the role of ADF in cells and may also be relevant to the treatment of actin-based motility disorders.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is widely used in the food industry and is often substituted for glucose in beverages and processed foods. The present study provides evidence that fructose ingestion results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food intake. The results also have implications for the development of novel strategies to reduce the consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages. This study also provides evidence that the effects of sugar on brain and behavior may be influenced by the type of sugar ingested. This study suggests that the use of glucose versus fructose in the food supply may be a useful strategy to reduce the consumption of sugar-sweetened beverages and the associated health risks. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is complex, with a recent arrival of Malagasy people, but the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which will be useful for the study of human evolution and the settlement history of Madagascar. We show that the emotional content of Facebook posts influences the emotions of people who view those posts. This is a form of emotional contagion, in which the emotions of others influence our own. We show that this occurs even when the posts are not in-person interactions, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social networks, and for the way that we understand the influence of social networks on our emotions.

The ribosome is a complex machine that translates messenger RNA (mRNA) into a protein. The mRNA sequence is a critical component of this process, and many modifications can be made to the mRNA sequence to alter translation. In this study, we show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can alter the translation process. We show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA can alter the rate of translation and the products of translation. This study provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on translation and may lead to the development of new strategies for the therapeutic modulation of protein levels. (Read more)

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the temperature at which it replicates in the nasal cavity is cooler than the core body temperature. We show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is dependent on the innate immune response of infected cells. We also show that the innate immune response of infected cells is less efficient at cooler temperatures. These findings have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Read more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. In this study, we show that the type IV pili system of the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is involved in sensing the mechanical activity of the pili, and that this sensing is used by the bacteria to regulate their surface attachment. Our results suggest that the pili are a mechanosensitive sensor, and that the pili-mediated surface sensing system is a mechanism used by P. aeruginosa to regulate its virulence.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. However, the impact of pesticides on aquatic ecosystems is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species of conservation concern in Iowa. We also show that the virus spread rapidly among deer during the winter months, when human hunting is at its peak. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide health crisis. The disease is thought to be driven by chronic inflammation, but the evidence for this is based on the presence of microgliosis and cytokines in the brain of animal models of AD. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric forms of amyloid-β (Aβ) are the primary drivers of inflammation in neurons, which in turn trigger the activation of microglia. Our results suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. Our faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, provides evidence for the earliest known economic exploitation of chickens. We show that the frequency of chicken bones at Maresha is more than twice as high as at any other site in the Southern Levant, and that the ratio of female to male chicken bones is 2:1, which is a clear indication of economic exploitation. Our results are supported by a survey of chicken bones from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the folding pathway is not known for many proteins. The folding of a single protein, maltose binding protein, was studied by a combination of methods that allowed the identification of the folding pathway. The results indicate that the folding of the protein is not a one-step process, but rather involves distinct steps.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the cellular conditions that lead to the formation of Np4 and the mechanisms by which they are decapped remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to decape triphosphorylated Np4, also decapes dinucleoside diphosphates and diphosphates, and that it does so by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decape triphosphorylated Np4. Our results suggest that the manner in which Np4-capped 5′ ends are recognized by RppH may be a key determinant of the rate at which the decapping reaction proceeds, and thus the timing of the subsequent degradation of the RNA.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to treat sepsis, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. Here, we show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis. Our results suggest that citrulline could be used as a therapeutic strategy to treat sepsis and other conditions in which immune dysfunction is a major factor in the development of the disease.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This information is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. This information is also essential for understanding the impact of humans on the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves at a constant rate, despite external perturbations, and is characterized by a critical state. SOC is observed in a wide variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, fire fronts, neural networks, and financial markets. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this paper is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control, and its mechanical properties are limited. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by mechanical strain, and its electronic properties can be tuned by strain. This work provides a new way to control the electronic properties of diamond, and it also provides a new way to control the mechanical properties of diamond. This work also provides a new way to control the electronic properties of diamond, and it also provides a new way to control the mechanical properties of diamond.

The study of plant defense mechanisms against pathogens is of great importance for the development of sustainable agriculture. In this work, we report the antifungal activity of a unique structure and mode of action of a plant-derived peptide. The antifungal activity of the peptide was demonstrated against multiple plant fungal pathogens, and the mode of action was elucidated. The results provide a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the viability of sperm. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the viability of sperm by providing a source of energy-related proteins. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work also provides a framework for future studies of the molecular basis of sex differences in the female reproductive tract. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping to control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to VWF switches the receptor to a second state with faster binding, providing a mechanism for the observed gain of function. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD. The results also suggest that the switch is a general mechanism for triggering binding of receptors to ligands.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of ACI makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Observations of ACI are challenging because of the difficulty in simultaneously measuring aerosols and clouds. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can measure aerosols and clouds simultaneously. We use this instrument to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, which is consistent with expectations. However, the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence is lower than that inferred from protein evidence. This study provides a method to determine the temperature of Earth’s surface based on the thermostability of enzymes. The results show that the surface temperature of Earth was higher in the Archean than in the present, consistent with the isotopic evidence.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow and play important roles in many physiological and pathological processes. Ion channels are also the targets of many drugs. Ion channels are classified into different families, each of which has its own unique structure and function. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is one of the most important K+ channels in the heart and is involved in cardiac arrhythmia. We found that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 600,000 deaths each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion, a process that has been the subject of intense study for over a century. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the physical properties of the host erythrocyte, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding represents a major change in our understanding of malaria invasion, suggesting it is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and energy storage. However, its electronic properties are difficult to control due to its high symmetry. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its electronic properties can be tuned reversibly by strain engineering. This work provides a new way to control the electronic properties of diamond, which will be useful for its applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We also show that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for the development of strategies to reduce the impact of influenza virus infection in low humidity environments. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain does this remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but suddenly decreases whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based solely on sequential transition probability over lexical and syntactic categories, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The Wnt pathway is one of the most important signaling pathways in vertebrates. It is involved in the development of the nervous system, the immune system, and the digestive system. It is also involved in the growth and differentiation of cells. The Wnt pathway is also involved in the development of cancer. The Wnt pathway is activated by a variety of mechanisms, including mutations in the genes that encode the pathway components. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat vigorously, and this effect is blocked by lesions of the dopamine system. Here we show that stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat, and that dopamine lesions or antagonists block this effect. We also show that dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area and substantia nigra do not play a role in this process. Instead, we show that stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat by stimulating the dopamine system in a region caudal to the ventral tegmental area. This region, which we term peri-locus coeruleus, contains neurons that project to the nucleus accumbens, a brain region that is important for reward and motivation. Thus, we propose a circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and productivity, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria is therefore a key technology for sustainable agriculture. Here, we report the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology could be used to improve the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in agriculture, and could also be used to engineer nitrogen-fixing symbioses for industrial applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by providing early alerts of deforestation to local communities and incentivizing them to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated in the program. However, the estimated effects are imprecise, and the results are not statistically significant. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are made up of cellular tissue and are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. Instead, the spider outsources its hearing to its web, which acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The spider supersizes its web to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of sensory function in animals. This study may also inspire the design of new acoustic sensors and actuators for a wide range of applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, thus limiting the temperature increase to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to be a major public health concern, with over 300 million confirmed cases and over 5.4 million deaths worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical step in controlling the pandemic. Recombinant subunit vaccines are a well-established and safe class of vaccines that are suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing. Here we report the design of a SARS-CoV-2 receptor-binding domain (RBD) subunit vaccine candidate that is highly manufacturable, immunogenic, and cross-reactive with variants of concern. This vaccine candidate may be a useful addition to the global vaccine arsenal.

The study of the role of ALK in human cancer has been greatly advanced by the discovery of secreted ALKAL proteins as ligands. However, the role of ALK in the development of the neural crest, a group of cells that gives rise to a variety of tissues and organs, has not been investigated. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK/ligands activate zebrafish ALK/ligand receptors, and that loss of ALK function in zebrafish causes a complete loss of neural crest cells. Our results provide evidence that ALK/ligand signaling is involved in neural crest development. This study also provides a model for studying the role of ALK/ligand signaling in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This model could be used to study the role of ALK/ligand signaling in human cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis from its progenitor Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is one of the most important events in the history of human disease. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from Eurasia dating from the Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which provide insights into the evolution and ecology of plague during this critical period of development. Our results suggest that plague was not a disease of humans until the Neolithic, and that it was nonflea-adapted and likely existed in a single lineage for millennia. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. These data provide insights into the early history of plague and its relationship to humans and their domestic animals. (Less)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors.

The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural soils is a key determinant of global climate change. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to intensive crop production has released massive amounts of C to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in reducing this C loss remains highly uncertain. We show that the management of perennial pastures can sequester more carbon in soil than annual cropping systems, highlighting the potential of well-managed grasslands to mitigate climate change. Our results also highlight the importance of incorporating legumes and manure into annual cropping systems to enhance soil health and carbon storage. These findings have important implications for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We also present a publicly accessible web tool, SpillOver, that allows users to explore the results and to investigate the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the chemical basis for this trait is poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a chemical basis for the evolution of a visually attractive reward for vertebrate pollinators. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations and invasions, which have shaped the genetic structure of the population today. However, the history of Europe during the period between the migrations of the Celts and the arrival of the Slavs is largely unknown. Here we present the genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived at the end of the Roman Empire and during the early Middle Ages. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of these women was shaped by a mixture of European and non-European populations. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides insights into the history of Europe during the period of major demographic changes. (Less)

The emergence of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) has caused a severe public health concern. The virus is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how these bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of the cross-species transmission of bat coronaviruses and the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. We report the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our findings highlight the utility of mNGS in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, and where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to monitor the pathogen landscape in other settings. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The lagging strand of the eukaryotic genome is replicated in short fragments called Okazaki fragments. The enzyme responsible for this process is DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This study also provides a unique platform for the study of the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme in other organisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. The RNA world is a proposed stage in the evolution of life in which genetic information was stored in RNA molecules rather than in proteins. In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template. This polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA, amplify RNA templates, and synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Thus, the polymerase ribozyme is a step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

This paper introduces a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This work also provides a proof of concept for a new type of urban monitoring that can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The clinical manifestations of severe and critical patients are similar, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment is mainly supportive. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, can improve the clinical outcomes of severe and critical patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the existence of copper-binding natural products in fungi is less well known. Here we report the discovery of a copper-binding natural product, xanthocillin, in Aspergillus fumigatus. Xanthocillin is secreted and has antimicrobial properties, and it is copper dependent. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in other filamentous fungi suggests that this is a widespread mechanism for the regulation of copper homeostasis in fungi. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the role of fungi in the environment and human health. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The formation of silica polymorphs in sedimentary rocks is a well-known process on Earth. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous silica is a product of multiple aqueous fluid infiltration. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk and the evolutionary impact of frost events on plants and animals are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in response to climate warming, and that species in regions that are currently frost-free are likely to be affected in the future. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the role of Th17 cells in the development of disease is not well understood. We found that Th17 cells, which express both IL-17A and IFN-γ, are required for the development of colitis in a Th17 transfer model. Th17 cells were required for the development of a subset of Th1-like cells, which express IFN-γ and the transcription factor T-bet. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which control voluntary muscle movement. The disease is progressive, and death is usually due to respiratory failure. The cause of the disease is unknown, and there are no effective treatments. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study the disease and develop new treatments. This method will also enable the rapid production of large numbers of motor neurons for disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening. This will greatly advance ALS research and development of new treatments. The role of the microbiome in the biology of arthropod vectors is just beginning to be understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector, the blacklegged tick, I. scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We identify a protein, antifreeze glycoprotein, that is expressed by the vector and is responsible for altering the microbiota. We also identify a mechanism by which this protein alters the permeability of the gut and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, which are critical for the survival of the pathogen in the vector. These findings provide insight into the biology of vector-borne disease transmission. (Read more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The study of the early history of the tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin and evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we report the discovery of a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new taxon adds important information about the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group and provides insights into the evolution of the avian tail.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for animals to adapt to their environment, and it is also important for animals to be camouflaged. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during vertebrate evolution, and that the mechanism of color change is the same in all cases.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, including breast cancer, and is associated with the emergence of cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for tumor initiation and relapse. CSCs are characterized by their ability to self-renew and to give rise to differentiated cells, and are thought to be responsible for the metastatic potential of tumors. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG is methylated at an m6A residue in the 3′-UTR, and this methylation is reduced in the presence of hypoxia. ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of breast cancer cells that exhibit cancer stem cell characteristics, and knockdown of ALKBH5 expression in breast cancer cells reduces their capacity for tumor initiation. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. (Read more)

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was a major innovation, and the source of the parchment has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe biotic crisis of the Phanerozoic and has been linked to the release of greenhouse gases, the initiation of the carbon isotope excursion, and the onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle. Here we present a precise age model for the extinction and its aftermath, which will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will allow insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion and will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in various biological processes, including circadian rhythm, cancer, and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is not well understood. Here, we report the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific deletion of RORα (RORαΔIEC) in mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2, and we have compared the structure of the spike in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G mutation is associated with a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.
