The chemical behavior of matter is one of the most fundamental aspects of science. It is the basis of chemistry, and it is also the foundation of many other fields, such as geology, metallurgy, and biology. In this paper, we show that the chemical behavior of matter can be described in terms of two fundamental properties of atoms: electronegativity and chemical hardness. We show that these two properties change with pressure, and we show that they can be used to predict and explain many chemical phenomena.

We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been a major driver of global fire activity over the past century. We also show that climate change has been a major driver of fire activity over the past century, but that climate change has been largely offset by human ignitions. Our results suggest that climate change may be slowing, but that human ignitions may be increasing, the global fire regime. This highlights the importance of both climate and human drivers of fire regimes and the need to consider both in future projections.

The mutualism between animals and their symbiotic microbes is one of the most successful and widespread forms of life on Earth. However, the mechanisms that regulate the stability of these associations are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan by the host animal is sufficient to maintain the stability of the symbiotic microbial community. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the conditions in which it lives. This glycan-mediated control of symbiont stability may be a common mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This study also highlights the importance of glycans in the mutualism between animals and their microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of word embeddings to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent discourse atoms. We model the generative process that generates a sequence of words as a mixture of these latent topics. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This method can be applied to a wide range of domains, including social media, news, and medical records.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This study shows that the bacterium was repeatedly reintroduced into European harbors from Asia, via the ancient Silk Road, over this period. This finding challenges the prevailing view that the Black Death was the consequence of a single introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the functioning of marine ecosystems. However, the population dynamics of asteroids are poorly understood, and their role in marine ecosystems is largely unknown. Here, we report the discovery of a densovirus (SSaDV) that is the most likely cause of the mass mortality of asteroids. This is the first report of a densovirus causing mass mortality of asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most common hematological malignancies, and the prognosis of patients is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is important for the development of more efficient therapies. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects, and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We also generated an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. The settlement history of Madagascar is also unique, as we found that the settlement happened in a sex-biased way, with a faster settlement of Madagascar from Africa than from Asia. Finally, we found that the genetic structure of Madagascar is also influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a spatially heterogeneous way. These results are important for the understanding of the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. They also provide a framework for the study of the human history of the rest of the African continent. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, a key enzyme in the metabolism of glycerol. We found that the protein interacts with the enzyme and that the RNA encoding the protein interferes with the RNA’s ability to repress the expression of genes involved in carbon utilization. These results demonstrate that the translation product of the RNA can compete with the RNA for its target mRNA. This is an example of a mechanism that can be used to control the expression of genes in bacteria. This mechanism may be important in the regulation of carbon utilization in bacteria.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our algorithm can be used to optimize the CDR sequences of an antibody to improve its binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants. We have demonstrated that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also be relevant to the development of other protein molecules. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their knowledge is critical for the proper management of agricultural production. However, the information they provide is often difficult to access and use. We show how to transform the original categorical crop ratings into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of harnessing the power of the “people as sensors” network to provide a more complete picture of agricultural production, and to improve the accuracy of agricultural monitoring systems.

Language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. This ability is thought to be supported by sustained, elevated neural activity. However, other work has suggested that short-term synaptic facilitation can also contribute to memory. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. We show that these changes can be used to read back information about the past, and that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key aspect of the evolution of life on Earth. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of plants, and the molecular signature of this transition is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. Our results suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the region in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this drought by a factor of five to six. This is due to a combination of the warming of the climate and the intensification of the rainfall extremes. Our results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This is of particular importance in the context of the upcoming Paris climate agreement, where the region is one of the most vulnerable to climate change. Our results also show the importance of downscaling climate model simulations to the regional scale, where the impact of climate change is most pronounced. This is a key step in the process of developing adaptation strategies for the region. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known anthropogenic quasicrystal was discovered in a sample of red trinitite, the only material that was present at the time of the first nuclear test explosion. The discovery of this material provides a unique link between the past and the present, and it demonstrates that the conditions for the discovery of quasicrystals are still present today.

Photosynthesis is the primary process by which life on Earth is sustained. The core of this process is the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The conversion of this energy to chemical energy is accomplished by the transfer of electrons from water to carbon dioxide, and the capture of these electrons is accomplished by the binding of light-harvesting pigments to the reaction center of photosystem II. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis. Neuroactive protein kinase ASK1 is involved in neuroinflammation, but the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes reduced neuroinflammation in the later stage of EAE, whereas ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is very likely due to anthropogenic warming. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions, which are associated with acute human and ecosystem impacts.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility observed in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic approaches. This work is the first to report cross-national evidence of negativity biases in the form of physiological reactions to news content. It also provides the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results are consistent with the hypothesis that humans are predisposed to react more strongly to negative information, and they help account for the prevalence of negative news content around the world. The results also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) channel is a key regulator of cellular physiology, but its function is dysregulated in a number of human diseases. Here, we report the identification of mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 that result in constitutive activation of the Ca2+ channel, and thus contribute to the pathogenesis of Stormorken syndrome. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of the dysregulation of the Ca2+ channel, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spreading of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on endocytosis and that the release of aggregates requires active transport. These findings provide a model for the study of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of the submandibular salivary gland in the immune regulation of bats and the potential of the submandibular salivary gland as a target for antiviral therapy. This study may also provide a deeper understanding of the role of the submandibular salivary gland in the immune regulation of bats and the potential of the submandibular salivary gland as a target for antiviral therapy. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the metabolic reprogramming that occurs in cancer is a major driver of tumor growth. One of the most important metabolic changes in cancer is the up-regulation of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. This one-carbon unit is then used to build nucleic acids, and thus cell growth. We show that targeting SHMT in cancer cells blocks tumor growth, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. This work provides a metabolic rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer, and a metabolic target for cancer treatment. This work also provides a metabolic rationale for the use of pyrazolopyrans as a class of SHMT inhibitors. This work also provides a metabolic rationale for the use of pyrazolopyrans as a class of SHMT inhibitors.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. However, the proteins that form inclusions are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. We show that the proteins that form inclusions of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a unifying hypothesis for the pathogenesis of ALS. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the early evolution of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils. This study presents a detailed analysis of Montsechia vidalii, a plant that was first described more than 100 y ago. The study of Montsechia suggests that it was an aquatic plant, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that aquatic habitats played a major role in the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The study of ancient viruses is important for understanding the evolution of viruses and the impact of viruses on human evolution. Here we present the genomes of five ancient viruses from human remains that lived between ∼0.5 and ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with climate models. This finding is important because it provides a more accurate estimate of future sea level rise, which is important for coastal planning and protection.

Pain is a major health problem in America, and the elderly are more likely to report pain than those in midlife. However, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife today. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that the elderly have had more pain than the midlife in each successive birth cohort, and that this pattern is driven by the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of structure and reactivity, which is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease highlights the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of early treatment in the prevention of disease progression. This study provides a proof of concept for the use of remdesivir in the treatment of other viral diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The mutualism between animals and their symbiotic microbes is one of the most successful and widespread forms of life on Earth. However, the mechanisms that regulate the stability of these associations are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan by the host animal is sufficient to maintain the stability of the symbiotic microbial community. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the conditions in which it lives. This glycan-mediated control of symbiont stability may be a common mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This study also highlights the importance of glycans in the mutualism between animals and their microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have increased by 600% since 1980. This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates by half, while maintaining high levels of respect for teachers, by encouraging teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This is a scalable intervention, which can be implemented in schools across the country.

DNA alkylation is one of the major sources of DNA damage in living cells. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion is recognized by pol II with high fidelity, whereas the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion is recognized with high mutagenesis. The minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II is involved in modulating the translocation of alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions must first be cleaved sequentially by cell-surface proteases, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. We show that the first cleavages are required for infection into human lung-derived cells, but have little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

This paper describes the results of a large-scale experiment and observational study that examined the impact of increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria. The results show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available by 50% led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8% in the experimental study and 78.8% in the observational study. These results are robust to the inclusion of covariates, and the results are not explained by rebound effects. These findings have important implications for the food service industry and for the future of sustainable diets.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We applied quantitative proteomics to a panel of oncogenes and found that the surfaceome is remodeled in a cell autologous fashion, and that the glycoproteome is also remodeled. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of covalent glycan tags for cell surface protein capture. This method is a significant advance over current methods that use antibodies, and should be broadly applicable to other systems. The results also suggest that the surfaceome may be a useful target for cancer therapy. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of covalent glycan tags for cell surface protein capture. This method is a significant advance over current methods that use antibodies, and should be broadly applicable to other systems. The results also suggest that the surfaceome may be a useful target for cancer therapy.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has a large number of mutations, and the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the disease caused by SARS-CoV-2. (Read more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats, and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in cortical astrocytes to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, leading to up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression and cerebral edema. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. It arises when we have a large dataset and wish to find the strongest associations. This is a difficult problem, because we have to set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step in the development of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs has been difficult to achieve, and the development of ECs has been limited to the use of pluripotent stem cells. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly induce the generation of functional ECs from human adult skin fibroblasts. This study provides a new approach for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 provides a new strategy for the treatment of vascular disorders. These findings will contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies for vascular disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are a large family of transmembrane receptors that are involved in a wide variety of biological processes. In the last few years, two new RTKs have been identified, which are involved in the development of the eye and the skin. These two RTKs, anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk), have been shown to be oncogenic in different types of cancer. Here, we show that these two RTKs have physiological ligands and that these ligands are essential for the development of the eye and the skin.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem worldwide. Although the molecular basis of T2D is complex, the role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function is still unclear. Herein, we report a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and β-cell function. We found that STING deficiency in β-cells and peripheral tissues impaired insulin secretion, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired insulin secretion. Moreover, STING deficiency in β-cells decreased nuclear localization of Pax6, a transcription factor that is required for insulin gene expression. These findings establish the pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These results also provide a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and are responsible for occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. Using this interaction, we demonstrated that the viral genome is packaged into virions in a sequence-dependent manner. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions.

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate that YAP/TAZ is activated by disturbed flow and plays a critical role in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of a new class of antiatherosclerotic drugs. This study also provides a new target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study may also provide a new perspective for the study of the role of YAP/TAZ in other diseases. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has likely contributed to some of the increase. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the need for increased management of human-caused wildfires to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

This paper introduces a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. This method can be used to monitor the physical appearance of cities over time and to study the physical dynamics of cities. This method can also be used to study the physical appearance of cities in other countries.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we report the identification of a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a receptor of natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has recently emerged as a cause of severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The virus has been shown to replicate in human cells, but the time course of infection and the rate of viral production are unknown. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and that the time between cell infection and viral production is short. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load by ∼2 d. However, the treatment is most effective when given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. These results can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals shed their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. The cause of bleaching is the overheating of zooxanthellae, which is often attributed to the direct impact of heat on the photosynthetic apparatus. However, our results show that the underlying processes are more complex and involve the catabolism of amino acids, which in turn affects the host’s metabolic capacity and the functioning of the symbiosis. Our findings provide insights into the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis and may help to explain the resilience of some coral species to environmental stress. This may help to identify the underlying mechanisms that contribute to the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis and the resilience of some coral species to environmental stress. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the organism from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the maintenance of homeostasis. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger the activation of JNK signaling, the dysbiosis of the microbiome, and the loss of intestinal barrier function. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our results identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, and they highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to treat intestinal tumors and restore host–microbe homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients relapse, and the majority of patients die. The identification of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis, may help to improve the treatment of breast cancer. Here we show that the activation of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinase-like receptor ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Furthermore, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can inhibit the growth of breast cancer patient-derived xenografts and improve the response to chemotherapy. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the treatment of breast cancer. (Read more)

The timing of the last deglaciation is one of the most important questions in Quaternary science. The start of deglaciation is marked by a change in climate and sea level, but the mechanisms that triggered the change are still debated. Here we show that a volcanic eruption series, which started at the beginning of the last deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a change in the Southern Hemisphere climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that the majority of catches come from rivers with high levels of human impact and biodiversity loss. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished, and that these populations are particularly vulnerable to the impacts of fishing. Our results highlight the need for improved management of inland fisheries, and the importance of including them in conservation and development planning. Our data can be used to inform the design of effective policies to protect freshwater biodiversity and food security. (Less)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅

The ability to regenerate is a defining characteristic of the nervous system, and the ability to regenerate in the adult mammalian CNS is lost with age. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate in the adult nervous system may be more robust than previously thought.

The process of recombination is essential for the proper functioning of the genome, but the details of its spatial organization are not well understood. We use a population of wild monkeyflowers to precisely locate the boundaries of historic crossovers, which are the sites of recombination. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no evidence of recombination, and others showing intense activity. The distribution of recombination boundaries defines a large number of hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The general pattern is similar to that observed in yeast, as well as in positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9–knockout mice, suggesting that recombination initiation described here in Mimulus may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of resting state networks (RSNs), which are topographically organized and are thought to reflect functional properties of the brain. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network, but that this RSN is subordinated in Parkinson’s disease. We also show that the dominant RSN is deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. These results provide a direct link between the metabolic organization of the brain and its functional properties, and have implications for the understanding of the neurobiology of disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. The 5′ cap structure is also found on tRNA and rRNA. Here we report the discovery of a 5′ NAD+ cap structure on nuclear and mitochondrial encoded messenger RNAs. This is the first example of a 5′ modification in eukaryotes that is not found on tRNA or rRNA.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and has no targeted therapy. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects the brain and the gut. The aim of the present study was to investigate the presence of gut dysfunction in alcohol-dependent subjects and to explore the possible link between gut permeability, gut microbiota, and psychological symptoms. We found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. This study also provides a rationale for the development of new therapeutic strategies for alcohol dependence. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not well understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. We show that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are likely to be exacerbated by biodiversity loss. This is because the additional impacts of warming will result in a shift in the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, requiring more species to maintain ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined impacts of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and the need to consider the thermal tolerance of species in the context of global change.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, involved in spatial navigation and memory. It is divided into superficial and deep layers, and the superficial layers are subdivided into three distinct zones. The superficial layers are thought to be important for the formation of spatial maps, but the anatomical and functional organization of the superficial layers is not well understood. Here, we used portable two-photon microscopes to examine the topographic arrangement of neurons in the superficial layers of MEC and adjacent parasubiculum during unrestrained behavior. Our results suggest that the superficial layers of MEC are organized into three distinct zones, and that grid cells are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These findings provide a framework for understanding the functional role of the superficial layers of MEC. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for the flowering of the host plant, but not for the flowering of the dodder. This is an important finding, as it illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of striatonigral fibers, which project from dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra to dopamine-containing medium spiny striatal neurons. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized type of nigral neuron, which we term “striosome–dendron bouquets,” that are innervated by striosomes, which are presumed to be involved in the control of mood and motivation. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We all have a sense of when we are connected to others, but how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for generating the heartbeat. SAN cells are responsible for generating the electrical signal that initiates each heartbeat. SAN cells are also responsible for maintaining heart rate in the face of changes in blood pressure and other hemodynamic demands. The electrical activity of SAN cells is regulated by a number of factors, including the amount of calcium in the sarcoplasmic reticulum, the amount of calcium in the cytoplasm, and the membrane potential. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a regulator of calcium dynamics in SAN cells and that STIM1 is important for the normal function of the SAN. These studies reveal a role for STIM1 in the regulation of calcium dynamics in SAN cells and provide insight into the mechanisms that underlie the normal function of the SAN. (Read more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA act synergistically in rice defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies for rice. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages, as it is in the case of the function of other ether lipid metabolizing enzymes.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative view, where information is maintained through adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biotechnology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plant cells. We also show that the delivery of siRNA to plant cells correlates with the delivery of the corresponding gene silencing, but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is important for the development of plant biotechnology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient pollution is one of the greatest threats to aquatic ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient pollution comes from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, ignoring the importance of small tributaries. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to large water bodies, and that their nutrient loads are often high for their size. Our findings suggest that small tributaries may be a significant contributor of coastal eutrophication, and that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include small tributaries. This could help protect valuable nearshore ecosystems and the services they provide to society.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This finding is relevant to the study of complex systems in general, and to the study of chemical networks in particular.

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain’s electrical activity. We show that the antibodies can change the way the brain is wired, and that this change can make the brain more susceptible to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This work may help to explain the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with this condition and may lead to the development of new treatments.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying abrupt climate change. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that this event was associated with anoxia and organic matter burial, which may have had a profound impact on the evolution of life on Earth.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Sex determination is one of the most important evolutionary processes, yet it is poorly understood in many species. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species with four possible sex classes. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple sex determination alleles can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics may be a general consequence of multiple sex determination alleles, and may be a key factor in the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is challenged by a number of factors that can lead to photoreceptor cell death. One of these factors is the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We show that the Fe chelator deferiprone (DFP) reduces the accumulation of bisretinoids in the retina of albino mice. This effect is associated with a reduction in the photodegradation of the bisretinoid A2E. These findings suggest that Fe plays a role in the photodegradation of bisretinoids and that DFP may be useful in the treatment of retinal diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of specialization is one of the most important processes in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional adaptations in separate structures. We show that this is not the case in siphonophores, a group of pelagic colonial cnidarians. We show that siphonophore specialists can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have evolved into specialists on other prey types. Our findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly modified structure. The evolution of the modern human hand is a key area of research, but the origins of some of its key features are poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a feature that is present in modern humans and Neandertals but absent in all earlier hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key feature of the human hand.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the metabolic reprogramming that occurs in cancer is a major focus of cancer research. One of the most important metabolic changes in cancer is the up-regulation of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and is a promising target for cancer therapy. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and show that these compounds are effective in cancer cells. However, one-carbon donor formate is required for cellular SHMT inhibition, and this is particularly important in cancer cells that are deficient in glycine import. Thus, we identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited for cancer therapy. This work provides a framework for the development of SHMT inhibitors as cancer therapeutics. This study provides evidence that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. This is important because, in many parts of the world, forests are the main source of food and nutrition security. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need for a more holistic approach to the management of natural resources, which is needed to ensure that the benefits of natural resources are shared equitably and sustainably.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the modern food system, allowing for the expansion of agricultural land and the production of more food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
